Line 11: Line 11:
On [[September 29]], [[2005]], the Saints left the Northern League, along with the [[Lincoln Saltdogs]], [[Sioux City Explorers]] and the [[Sioux Falls Canaries]] to found the [[American Association (21st century)|American Association]] for the [[2006]] season.
On [[September 29]], [[2005]], the Saints left the Northern League, along with the [[Lincoln Saltdogs]], [[Sioux City Explorers]] and the [[Sioux Falls Canaries]] to found the [[American Association (21st century)|American Association]] for the [[2006]] season.
  +   +
===Notable promotions===
  +
In an attempt to gain publicity in a city that hosts four major pro sports teams and a major college program, the Saints have grabbed headlines numerous times for their unique promotions.<ref name=espn>{{cite web
  +
| last = Rovell
  +
| first = Darren
  +
| year = [[April 17]], [[2006]]
  +
| url = http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/news/story?id=2411809
  +
| title = Another last laugh for the St. Paul Saints
  +
| publisher = ESPN.com
  +
| accessdate = 2006-04-18
  +
}}</ref>
  +
*In April 2006, the Saints announced that rubber boats would be given out during a [[May 27]], 2006 game, ostensibly to honor 30th anniversary of the television show ''[[The Love Boat]]''. However, details of the promotion indicate that it is intended as a jab at the [[Minnesota Vikings sex scandal|2005 sex scandal]] involving the [[Minnesota Vikings]], where several members of the team were allegedly involved in illicit behavior on a private cruise. The promotional rubber boats use the same color as the Vikings uniforms (purple and yellow) and are named ''Minnetonka Queen'' (a reference to [[Lake Minnetonka]], where the cruise took place).<ref name=espn />
  +
*In August 2003, the Saints held "Randy Moss Hood Ornament Night", poking fun at the Viking's wide receiver [[Randy Moss]]. Earlier that year, Moss was involved in an incident where he bumped a traffic control officer with his car while he attempted to make a turn.<ref name=espn />
  +
*During the 2002 [[Major League Baseball]] labor negotiations, the Saints out seat cushions with pictures of commisioner [[Bud Selig]] on one side and [[Major League Baseball Players Association|player's association]] Executive Director [[Donald Fehr]] on the other.<ref name=espn />
  +
*In 2002, in response to Selig's controversial decision to end the [[MLB All-Star Game]] in a 7-7 tie, the Saints gave out [[neckties]] (or "ties") with Bud Selig's image.<ref name=espn />

* [[Ila Borders]] (1997, first woman to pitch in a men's professional baseball league)

== St. Paul Saints (1884-1899) ==

Line 41: Line 53:
== St. Paul Saints (1900-1960) ==
== St. Paul Saints (1900-1960) ==
Another team called the Saints played minor league baseball as the farm club of the [[Los Angeles Dodgers|Brooklyn Dodgers]] in St. Paul until 1960. That team played in the [[American Association (20th century)|American Association]] along with its crosstown rivals the [[Minneapolis Millers]] (farm club of the [[San Francisco Giants|New York Giants]]). Both teams folded when the [[Minnesota Twins]] came to town in [[1961]]. [[Lexington Park]] served as the home stadium for most of those years.
Another team called the Saints played minor league baseball as the farm club of the [[Los Angeles Dodgers|Brooklyn Dodgers]] in St. Paul until 1960. That team played in the [[American Association (20th century)|American Association]] along with its crosstown rivals the [[Minneapolis Millers]] (farm club of the [[San Francisco Giants|New York Giants]]). Both teams folded when the [[Minnesota Twins]] came to town in [[1961]]. [[Lexington Park]] served as the home stadium for most of those years.
  +   +
